fileDesc.notesStmt:
<note type="work_relations" target="xxx." cert="high">
A late-stage draft, with printer's notes, of the essay "My Book and I," which was first published in Lippincott's in January 1887. Much of this essay appeared, slightly altered, in "A Backward Glance O'er Travel'd Roads," published in November Boughs in 1888.

bibl.author: Whitman, Walt
bibl.orgName: By permission of The British Library
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.

body.head: My Book and I.
body.p: Perhaps the best of a song heard, or of any and all true love, or life's fairest episodes, or sailors', or soldiers' trying scenes on land or sea, in the floating résumé of them, or any of them, long afterward, looking at the actualities away back past, with all ‸actualtheir practical excitations gone. How the soul loves to hover over such past experiences!reminiscences!

So here I sit, gossipping in the early candlelight of old age—I and my book—casting backward glances over our traveled road. After
2 2
completing, as it were, the journey, (a varied jaunt of years, rather, with many halts and gaps of intervals—or some lengthened ship-voyage wherein more than once the last hour had apparently arrived, and we seem'd certainly, gone going down—yet reaching port in a certain fashion and through all discomfitures at last_—After completing this Book,learneymy poems,‸ and letting an interval elapse to settle mattersthem, I am curious to review themall in the light of their own (‸strangely, originallyat the time unconscious, or mostly unconscious) intentions, with some of thecertain unfoldings of the thirty years they seek to embody. These GlancesThese glances therefore will probably blend the weft, of first purposes and speculations with the warp of that experience afterward, alys bringing strange developements.

Result of seven or eight stages and struggles extending through nearly thirty years, ‸O look upon "Leaves of Grass", ‸now, finished at last to the end of myits opportunities and powers, as my definitive carte visite to the coming generations of the New World*, if I may assume to say so. That I have not gained
note at bottom smaller type * note When Champollion, on his death-bed handed to the printer the revisedlostrevised proof of his "Egption Grammar" he said gaily, "Take care of these" "Be careful of this—it is my carte de visite to postera
the acceptance of my own time, but have fallen back on fond dreams of the future ("Still lives the song, though Regnar dies,")—that from a worldly and business point of view, L. of G. has been worse than a failure—that after thirty years of trial public criticism on the book, and myself as author of it shows marked anger and contempt more than any thing else,—("I find a solid line of
4 4
enemies to you everywhere"—letter from W.S.K. Boston, May 28, 1884)—and that solely for publishing it, I have been the
object of two or three to me pretty serious official buffetings—is ‸‸all probably no more than I ought to have expected. I had my choice when I commenced. I bid neither for soft eulogies, big money returns, nor the approbation of existing schools and conventions.
run in As fulfilled, or partially fulfilled, the best comfort of the whole business'—(after a small band of the dearest friends and upholders ever vouchsafed to man or ‸cause—book—doubtless all the more faithful and uncompromising—this little phalanx!—for being so few,) is, that‸—unstopp'd and unwork'd by any influence outside the soul within me—I have had my say entirely my own way, and put it add unerringly on record—the value thereof to be decided by time.

In calculating that decision, William O'Connor and Dr Bucke are far more peremptory than I am. Behind all else that can be, said I consider L of G. and its theory, with it as experiemental—as, in the deepest sense, I consider our American Republic itself to be, with its
5 5
theory. I think I have at least enough of philosophy not to be too ‸absolutely certain of any thing, or any results. In the second place, the volume is a sortie—whether to prove triumphant, and congruer its fa field of aim and escape and construction, onlynothing less than‸ a hundred years from now can ‸fully answer. I consider the point that I have positively gained a hearing to far more than make up for any and all other lacks and withholding. Essentially ‸that was from the first, and has remained throughout, the main object. Now that it is achieved, I am certainly contented to waive any otherwise momentous drawbacks, as of little account.
